title: EthereumTests.sln (silently) fails to execute any test fixtures from execution-spec-tests
body:
**Description**
Executing:
```
dotnet test Ethereum.Blockchain.Block.Test/Ethereum.Blockchain.Block.Test.csproj
```
fails to find any of the [ethereum/tests](https://github.com/ethereum/tests) test fixtures that originate from the [ethereum/execution-spec-tests](https://github.com/ethereum/execution-spec-tests) repository. This is likely due to directory renaming (that took place in June) within execution-spec-tests, but probably existed in the propagated fixtures in ethereum/tests for much longer.

**Steps to Reproduce**
Use master (6472650d2c) or cancun (45c4cfcc02) and filter to reduce noise:
```
dotnet test Ethereum.Blockchain.Block.Test/Ethereum.Blockchain.Block.Test.csproj --filter FullyQualifiedName~Ethereum.Blockchain.Block.Test.Pyspecs.VMTests
```

**Actual behavior**
Currently, no tests are ran and the command reports:
```
No test matches the given testcase filter `FullyQualifiedName~Ethereum.Blockchain.Block.Test.Pyspecs.VMTests` in /home/dtopz/code/github/NevermindETH/nethermind/src/Nethermind/Ethereum.Blockchain.Block.Test/bin/Debug/net7.0/Ethereum.Blockchain.Block.Test.dll
```

Modifying the path to a directory that contains JSON fixtures resolves the issue, but probably it'd be desirable to search directories recursively under the provided directory to find all JSON fixtures in the sub-directories under the provided directory. Modifying one of the test files as following works, for example:
```diff
diff --git a/src/Nethermind/Ethereum.Blockchain.Block.Test/Pyspecs/VMTests.cs b/src/Nethermind/Ethereum.Blockchain.Block.Test/Pyspecs/VMTests.cs
index 9bdcec07bd..45d4419f5b 100644
--- a/src/Nethermind/Ethereum.Blockchain.Block.Test/Pyspecs/VMTests.cs
+++ b/src/Nethermind/Ethereum.Blockchain.Block.Test/Pyspecs/VMTests.cs
@@ -17,7 +17,7 @@ public class VMTests : BlockchainTestBase
 
     public static IEnumerable<BlockchainTest> LoadTests()
     {
-        var loader = new TestsSourceLoader(new LoadBlockchainTestsStrategy(), "Pyspecs/vm");
+        var loader = new TestsSourceLoader(new LoadBlockchainTestsStrategy(), "Pyspecs/frontier/opcodes");
 
         return (IEnumerable<BlockchainTest>)loader.LoadTests();
     }
```

**Expected behavior**
Tests should run and generate the following output:
```
Running 009-fork=Shanghai at 14:14:21.067649
Running 007-fork=London at 14:14:21.067634
Running 006-fork=Berlin at 14:14:21.067589
Running 005-fork=Istanbul at 14:14:21.067584
Running 002-fork=Byzantium at 14:14:21.067614
Running 008-fork=Merge at 14:14:21.067622
Running 004-fork=ConstantinopleFix at 14:14:21.067614
Running 003-fork=Constantinople at 14:14:21.067625
Running 000-fork=Frontier at 14:14:21.067639
Running 001-fork=Homestead at 14:14:21.067617

Passed!  - Failed:     0, Passed:    10, Skipped:     0, Total:    10, Duration: 580 ms - Ethereum.Blockchain.Block.Test.dll (net7.0)
```

**Desktop (please complete the following information):**
Please provide the following information regarding your setup:
 - Operating System: Linux
 - Version: Ubuntu 22.04
 - Installation Method: Built on command-line.
 - Consensus Client: None

**Additional context**
Background: I help maintain execution-spec-tests. I'd love to see Nethermind use the execution-spec-test fixtures directly from the repo's releases instead of via ethereum/tests. Currently these are available on the repo's [Github releases page](https://github.com/ethereum/execution-spec-tests/releases/).
(You'd need to use `fixtures_develop.gar.gz`: https://github.com/ethereum/execution-spec-tests/releases/download/v1.0.5/fixtures_develop.tar.gz). We're happy to discuss the best way for you get these artifacts - please reach out. But currently using ethereum/tests will result in a slower feedback loop and a delay in between the execution-spec-tests release and when they'd be available for use via ethereum/tests.
